6.430 Performance Management
Performance (

) Commitments and objectives enable managers, management officials, and conﬁdential management/program analysts to develop action items that turn, carry out the Service’s day-to-day operations, linking their activities to or IRS’ goals and objectives. Each commitment or objective should relate to, support, one or more of the responsibilities listed in the performance agreement. (

) The supervisor should share his or her commitments with the employee to the employee’s commitments or objectives being developed. The discusses how the employees commitments or objectives should link to the organizational workplans and balanced measures. Note: For additional information, see IRM
, Managing Statistics in a Measurement System - The IRS Balanced Measurement System. (

) The supervisor should review documents such as organizational program plans, business plans, site-speciﬁc issues/priorities, Equal Employment Opportunity/Affirmative Action plans, and balanced measures data when preparing to discuss with the employee what needs to be included in his or commitments or objectives. (
) The supervisor and employee should identify the most important areas on which to focus. (
) The supervisor and the employee jointly develop the employee’s or objectives, with the reviewing official having the ﬁnal authority for of the performance agreement. (
) Supervisors and employees should think of commitments and objectives as “What” and responsibilities as the “How.” for (
) Generally, a limited number of commitments or objectives should be estab- Well lished to represent challenges for the employee. Each commitment or should be results oriented. or (

) When developing the commitments or objectives, discussions should the means of accomplishing the commitments or objectives, such as: timing, expected performance levels, methods of measurement, and level organizational support (funding, staff, and training) needed. (

) The following should be considered when writing commitments or a. State speciﬁcally what is to be accomplished, not general tasks, responsibilities of an ongoing job. b. Describe challenging but realistic actions the employee can c. Maintain a “line of sight” to the goals of the Service. d. Include a clear timeframe for accomplishment, some commitments or jectives may take less than one year to accomplish and others may longer. If the timeframe is longer than one year, interim milestones be identiﬁed in the performance agreement. e. Verify they are achievable and can be monitored. Focus on describing outcomes or results that will exist when the commitment or objective been successfully achieved. f. Outline required organizational resources or support. Consider resources from the employee’s assigned organization, as well as other parts of the IRS.
Note: For additional information, see IRM 1.5.1, Managing Statistics in a Balanced Measurement System - The IRS Balanced Measurement System.

Program for Evaluating Managers, Officials and Conﬁdential Management/Program g. Keep in mind how the commitments or objectives will be measured, the employee will demonstrate achievement. h. For managers only: ensure the commitments or objectives are speciﬁc enough so that direct reports can understand them. i. Focus on individual actions that support organizational priorities. j. Begin each commitment or objective with the phrase “I will” to frame the employee will do rather than what the organization will achieve. k. When drafting commitments and objectives, use an explanatory tive phrase such as “so that”, “in order to” or “to ensure that” to tie each commitment or objective to an expected result or outcome. l. Consider what data sources will be used to monitor progress in meeting commitments or objectives. Note: For more information on writing commitments, see Writing Performance Commitments, A Reference Guide for Managers and Management at and ELMS self-instructional Writing Commitments for Managers and Man- agement Officials. (
) After the supervisor and the employee discuss and agree on commitments objectives, they are recorded under Part I, Section B of the appropriate mance agreement form. (

) The supervisor and the reviewing official make the ﬁnal determination the commitment or objective should be included in the performance if the supervisor and the employee cannot agree on the commitments or tives. (
) It is important to document any changes in the commitments or objectives throughout the performance appraisal period. (

) Commitments or objectives should be qualitative in nature, but can and be guided by the organization’s quantitative performance measures. The reason for this restriction is fundamental to the intent of the balanced ment approach and critical to changing behaviors. If individuals are held accountable solely for achieving speciﬁc numerical targets, the natural response is to focus attention on the numbers and not on the actions. (

) Although employee engagement issues related to Leadership, Employee faction, Business Results, and Equal Employment Opportunity are proper areas that should be considered in evaluating managerial performance, manager performance commitments should be written in terms of the actions the manager can take to inﬂuence the employee survey numerical score. (

) Since the employee survey numerical scores do not reﬂect the speciﬁc the manager took to improve the issue affecting the workgroup performance, managerial performance commitments should not be written in terms of improving the quantitative score or the participation percentage. (

) The employee survey numerical score should only be considered an indicator pointing to areas which might need further consideration and may be used to determine the appropriate workgroup issues for development of managerial commitments. (

) Commitments based on organizational performance objectives, such as the employee survey, should focus primarily on what actions the manager will to improve the workgroup environment and bringing resolution to the issue where possible, since the survey scores may change for many reasons are outside of the managers ability to control. (

) The supervisor must discuss with the employee behaviors that will allow the employee to meet the Retention Standard for the fair and equitable treatment of taxpayers, circumstances that may result in a determination that the employee does not meet the Retention Standard for the fair and equitable treatment of taxpayers, and the potential impact of not meeting the Retention Standard. IRM Exhibit
, Performance Management Program for Evaluating BU & NBU Employees Assigned to CJEs provides examples of Retention Standard behavior that may result in a “Met” or “Not Met” rating.

) Discussions concerning the Retention Standard for the fair and equitable treatment of taxpayers may include: a. The potential impacts of not meeting the standard. c. Avoidance of use of the words “deliberately” or “intentionally” in behavior that does not meet the standard. d. A “Not Met” summary evaluation rating the employee ineligible for a performance award, within-grade (WIGI), career ladder promotion, competition for promotion, or completion of a probationary period, and may result in the employees removal from the position and/or the IRS. ) The supervisor should also document any other progress reviews held and provide a copy to the employee. Documented observations throughout the formance appraisal period serve as an aid in completing the mandatory mid- year progress review and the annual evaluation. The supervisor should identify the actions taken to accomplish commitments or objectives, and responsibili- ties. (

) The supervisor should focus on the employees performance as it relates to Retention Standard for the fair and equitable treatment of taxpayers and progress toward achieving commitments or objectives. If necessary, the super- visor should identify improvement opportunities. (

) At any point during the performance cycle, the supervisor and the employee can review and revise commitments or objectives to reﬂect changes in the pri- orities of the Service. • Changes may be needed for reasons such as: the expectations of com- mitments or objectives changed; or the Service’s mission, strategic business goals, or business plans changed; or the level of available support (e.g., staff, dollars, training) decreased or increased. • Changes to commitments or objectives must be made at least
days before the end of the performance appraisal period to avoid having to extend the appraisal period. (

) The supervisor may NOT use Records of Tax Enforcement Results (ROTERs) in monitoring progress against critical performance expectations. The ROTERs do not convey whether an individual performed well under his or her critical performance expectations. For additional information on ROTERs, see IRM
, Managing Statistics in a Balanced Measurement System - Section
, Certiﬁcation and Independent Review Processes. (

) If at any time during the appraisal period an employee’s performance in one more critical performance expectations (Responsibilities, Commitments or jectives, or the Retention Standard for the fair and equitable treatment of taxpayers) falls below the “Met” level, the manager must provide assistance. (

) The supervisor must consult with their servicing Labor Relations/Employee Relations Office regarding any performance rating of “Not Met” or “Minimally Satisfactory” to ensure that all parties understand the implications of failing improve. (

) Employees who do not meet the Retention Standard for the fair and treatment of taxpayers, Commitments or Objectives and/or Responsibilities should be counseled as early as possible in the appraisal period. Failure to improve or to sustain a “Met” rating could impact an employee’s ability to remain in his or her position. Failure to improve or to sustain a “Met” rating could also impact an employee’s salary review and cause the employee to ineligible for a pay increase under an IRS Payband System. (

) Before a supervisor begins the formal process of taking a action, the supervisor needs to be aware that he or she has certain options. The law provides for two different processes for taking performance-based actions: a. If a performance-based action is taken under
CFR Part
, a formal opportunity to improve is required. b. If a performance-based action is taken under the adverse action proce- dures of
CFR Part
, an opportunity period is not required. Note: Regardless of the process used, the supervisor must contact the servicing Labor Relations/Employee Relations Office for assistance. (
) “Not Met” ratings must be reviewed and approved by an official higher than rating official. (

) When an employee’s performance fails to meet established performance ex- pectations at an acceptable level in one or more critical performance expectations (i.e., Retention Standard for the fair and equitable treatment of taxpayers, Commitments or Objectives and/or Responsibilities), the must notify the employee in writing. This notice must advise the employee of the following: a. That his or her performance is unacceptable. b. Which critical performance expectation(s) are not being performed in an acceptable manner. c. The supervisor must consult with their servicing Labor Relations/Employee Relations Office regarding any performance rating of “Not Met” or “Minimally Satisfactory” to ensure that all parties understand the implications of failing improve. Employees who do not meet the Retention Standard for the fair and treatment of taxpayers, Commitments or Objectives and/or Responsibilities should be counseled as early as possible in the appraisal period. Failure to improve or to sustain a “Met” rating could also impact an employee’s salary review and cause the employee to ineligible for a pay increase under an IRS Payband System. ) A rating of record can be based only on the evaluation of actual job perfor- mance for the designated performance appraisal period. A supervisor must issue a rating of record that assumes a level of performance by an without an actual evaluation of that employee’s performance. (

) The performance appraisal is ﬁnal when it is issued to the employee with all appropriate reviews and signatures. Thus, the appraisal should not be discussed with the employee until all appropriate reviews and signatures been completed. (
) For positions covered by Performance Review Boards (PRB), the appraisal is not considered ﬁnal until the PRB has completed its process. (

) The supervisor should begin the performance appraisal meeting by the employee’s self-assessment, focusing on the areas of agreement the self-assessment and the supervisor’s assessment of the employee’s mance. (

) During the performance appraisal meeting, the supervisor should share a of the completed performance agreement with the employee and discuss openly the ratings and rationale for those ratings, with an eye towards consensus. For areas of disagreement, the supervisor should determine if information was overlooked. (

) The supervisor should consider the following when conducting an appraisal meeting: a. Always acknowledge the areas of outstanding performance, as well as areas for improvement to give balance to the appraisal. b. Focus on the future by jointly developing a plan of action to improve formance. d. Follow a problem solving approach. hired employees covered by the IRS Payband System who do not meet the IRS minimum appraisal period or do not have a rating of record from another Federal agency for the current performance appraisal period will not be eligible for a performance bonus or performance
